AUDIENCE

This document provides instructions for the general use of the operators accessing the Partnership Control Systems display terminals in the SB/SE, LBI, TE/GE, and Appeals Operation Divisions in the Campuses and Area/Industry Offices.
Table of Contents
Control System Chapter Overview 2.2.1
List of terms and deﬁnitions used throughout this IRM section

) IRM
, Information Technology (IT) Security, IDRS Security (
) This handbook provides instructions for the general use of the operators accessing the Partnership Control System display terminals in the and Area/Industry Offices. (
) These instructions provide explicit procedures for entering or extracting from the Partnership Control System. (
) The Partnership Control System uses the Integrated Data Retrieval (IDRS) Security System. Detailed instructions for the Security System are contained in IRM
, IDRS Terminal Responses, Security Command for IDRS Users. (
) The Security and Communications System (SACS) provide security and auditing for IDRS. (
) The IDRS Security System is designed to provide the protection deﬁned IRM
, Information Technology (IT) Security, Policy, and Guidance, conforms to the various laws and regulations deﬁned in IRM
Security Handbook, Exhibit

) The IDRS Security System provides identiﬁcation and authorization for input. • The Employee Security File contains signiﬁcant data required to recognize each employee authorized to use IDRS. • The Terminal includes terminal identiﬁcation to recognize each workstation capable of accessing IDRS.

(01-01-2011) Partnership Control System Chapter Overview
Partnership Control (
) All actions taken on IDRS, both authorized and unauthorized, are the IDRS audit trail. (

) The IDRS Security System is designed to provide protection to both the taxpayer and IDRS user. • The taxpayer must be protected from unauthorized disclosure of mation concerning their account as well as unauthorized access, inspection, and changes to it. • The IDRS user employee must be protected from other personnel their identiﬁcation to access or make changes to an account. (
) Taxpayers must be protected from: • Unauthorized disclosures of account information. • Unauthorized changes of account information. • Unauthorized accesses (UNAX) to account information. (
) Employees should exercise special precautions to identify the taxpayer or authorized representative when answering inquiries about a refund, justment or delinquent account. (

) When responding to telephone inquiries and walk-in taxpayers about a account, the employee handling the inquiry should obtain: a. Taxpayer’s name, address. b. Taxpayer Identiﬁcation Number (SSN or EIN). c. Document Locator Number (DLN), date or amount on notice or document received. d. Date and/or amount of refund, adjustment, payment or return. e. Type of notice or other communication received. (

) If a caller is unable to furnish enough information to establish that he/she actually is the taxpayer, the employee should request that the caller ﬁnd the information and call back. If the caller states he/she does not have formation and cannot obtain it, the employee should advise the caller to to the IRS office that generated the taxpayer correspondence. (

) Employees shall not provide Taxpayer Identiﬁcation Numbers over the telephone. Exception: Employees performing duties which require them to provide Taxpayer Identiﬁcation Numbers over the telephone will follow functional IRM guidelines (e.g. Employees staffing Toll Free Phone tions). (
) Walk-in taxpayers should not be given tax return information until they properly identiﬁed themselves. (

) Information concerning taxpayers will not be provided to third parties written authorization from the taxpayer. This is true even when the third requesting information has possession of a copy of the bill or notice in question. (

) Written authorization from the taxpayer is not restricted to a power of or to any speciﬁc form. The authorization must bear the taxpayer’s there is serious doubt whether the signature on the authorization is the er’s, offer to mail the information to the taxpayer’s address of record. ) It is equally important that each employee be protected from other personnel using their identiﬁcation. a. Users must properly safeguard their password in order to obtain the beneﬁts of the IDRS security system. b. Users must adhere to established sign-on and sign-off procedure. use of command codes SINON and SINOF will help provide protection the user. (
) It is essential that only properly authorized employees have access to IDRS. a. IDRS access must be requested using the OL

application. must be approved by the user’s manager and their Unit Security sentative (USR). IDRS user accounts can only be created by a home campus IDRS Security Officer or an IDRS Security User Administrator. For IDRS purposes, the home campus is the location where the user’s IDRS account is managed based on the user’s business organization. b. Changes to IDRS user accounts must be input by either the user’s Unit Security Representative (USR), their home campus IDRS Security Officer, or an IDRS Security User Administrator. These changes must approved by the user’s manager and their Unit Security Representative (USR). IRM
IDRS Security Handbook deﬁnes which changes be input by a USR and which can only be input by an IDRS Security Officer or IDRS Security User Administrator. IRM
also the procedures that must be followed to request changes to user accounts. c. User proﬁles should only contain those IDRS command codes to perform their official duties. (
) IDRS users are authorized to access only those accounts required to accom- plish their official duties. (
) IDRS users must not access their own or spouse/ex-spouse’s account, the account of a friend, relative or any account in which they have a personal ﬁnancial interest. (
) IDRS users must not access the account of another IRS employee unless it part of their official duties. (
) IDRS users must not access the account of a celebrity, business, or other prominent individual or entity unless it is part of their official duties. (
) Each IDRS user will be responsible for creating an IDRS password that is known by that user, and he/she is responsible for its security. (
) See IRM
for speciﬁc instructions on password management. (
) The command code SINON is used to sign-on to IDRS. (
) An employee must sign-on to IDRS before accessing or changing any on IDRS. The employee will accomplish this by inputting Command Code (CC)SINON ( See Exhibit

) that will verify whether or not the is authorized to use IDRS. The sign-on screen contains a brief paragraph ex- plaining the responsibilities and disciplinary actions that may result to all authorized users who misuse the system. A user who signs onto IDRS is ac- Internal Revenue Manual

also describes the procedures that must be followed to request changes to user accounts. c. User proﬁles should only contain those IDRS command codes necessary to perform their official duties.

) During sign-in, the user must ensure that the Production Training Indicator (PTI) is set appropriately. PTI’s are • P = for the production mode — no restriction • T = for the training mode — no restriction • R = for the research mode — restricted to selected users A banner across the top of the IDRS Access screen will let the user know if they are signed-on to production, training, or research mode. (
) The employee’s IDRS password is protected from viewing during the sign-on process. This ﬁeld is not displayed on the screen to help safeguard the password. (

) If an employee is veriﬁed as authorized to access IDRS ﬁles, the user will receive access to the “LOGON SUCCESSFUL ...” IDRS screen. This screen provides session information, production type, includes the Inf
onnect ID Terminal Identiﬁer; and provides banner information about unauthorized to the system and unauthorized access to taxpayer information. (

) The IDRS Security Officer in the home campus or an IDRS Security User ministrator can adjust the employee’s proﬁle for restricted PTI’s when the employee needs to obtain access to only one type of account. If no changes are made to the employee’s proﬁle, the employee will continue to have to any type of account. The restricted PTI’s are: • I = restricted access for IMF production accounts only • B = restricted access for BMF production accounts only • A = restricted access to IMF research accounts only • C = restricted access to BMF research accounts only (

) An employee cannot be signed on to more than one IDRS terminal at a time and cannot be signed on in both the production and training modes at the same time unless the employee is authorized for Dual SINON. (
) If an employee without Dual SINON is signed onto a terminal and signs on another IDRS terminal, the employee’s IDRS session is automatically closed on the ﬁrst terminal. (
) If an employee with Dual SINON signs on a third terminal, the employee’s IDRS sessions are closed on the ﬁrst two terminals and the employee proﬁle systemically locked. (
) As of January
: • IDRS will no longer generate a two-character Entry Code when users sign on IDRS. • Users will no longer add an Entry Code at the end of each IDRS action. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

Users must use command code SINOF or use the top X in the right corner to sign
off IDRS. Users must sign
off IDRS whenever they are going to be away from their workstation. In situations where users need to be away from their workstation for a brief period of time and it is impractical to sign
off IDRS (ie: they are in the process of inputting an adjustment or generating correspon
dence using CC LETER), the user should activate their password
protected screen lock to prevent an unauthorized user from accessing their IDRS account.

(
) If a user is signed on at one workstation and signs on to another the user account at the ﬁrst workstation will be automatically de-activated unless the user has been proﬁled for Dual Access. (
) See Exhibit
in this IRM for the SINOF input format and input instruc- tions. (

) The security system provides identiﬁcation and authorization for every input. The Employee Security File contains signiﬁcant data required to recognize each employee authorized to use IDRS. The Terminal Security File includes terminal identiﬁcation to recognize each terminal in the IDRS. (
) Training Mode connects employees to an IDRS training system where they access and modify fake taxpayer accounts. (
) Employees will be able to update a training account through real-time and will be able to view the updated effect on the account. (

) The employee’s user proﬁle in Training Mode is different from their employee proﬁle in Production Mode. When signed-on in Training Mode, employees only use command codes contained in their Training Proﬁle. Employees contact their manager or USR for instructions on modifying their Training Proﬁle. (
) All Training Mode actions are recorded in the IDRS audit trail. (
) All Training Mode security violations will be included in IDRS security reports. (
) When an IDRS user is signed on in the Training Mode, the terminal will be thorized for the same command codes as the user’s Training Proﬁle until he/ she signs off. (

) Training mode accounts may be restored to the original condition by two methods: a. by terminal input of command code RESTR to restore a speciﬁc an entire account, or an Audit Information Management System (AIMS) record. b. by daily (or periodic) restoration of the entire training ﬁle.
by terminal input of command code RESTR to restore a speciﬁc module, an entire account, or an Audit Information Management System (AIMS)
2.2 Partnership Control System

When operating in the Training Mode on production accounts (research no actual updating of any IDRS data can be made. All command codes, are otherwise used in exactly the same manner as when in the Production Mode.
2.2.1.3.12 (01-01-2011) General Security Reminders
workstation. (
) Users should know their Unit Security Representative (USR), Alternate and Terminal Security Administrators (TSAs) and how to contact them. (
) Users should know their Terminal Security Identiﬁer (TSID), their Unit and their IDRS Employee Number. (
) Users should periodically review the IRS Security Rules. (
) Users should check their user proﬁle regularly for changes. (
) Users should access only those accounts required to accomplish their duties. (
) Users should clear taxpayer account information from their IDRS screen prevent unauthorized disclosure of taxpayer information. (

) Users should retrieve all prints immediately from a printer. If someone print in the printer, it should be removed and shredded or placed into a container for disposing of sensitive information if the originator cannot be termined. (
) Command code RMODE authorizes an employee to use the command contained in their Training Proﬁle in a research mode.
Command code RMODE authorizes an employee to use the command codes contained in their Training Proﬁle in a research mode.
Control System Chapter Overview 2.2.1
) The research mode differs from production mode in that production ﬁles are accessed but not updated. It differs from training mode in that the training are not accessed. (

) The research mode is to be used only by: a. IDRS User Support staffs for researching production problems that be resolved only by accessing production data. b. Application development staffs for addressing issues that can be only by accessing production data. Application development staff use must be in compliance with IRM
Information Technology (IT) Security, Live Data (LD) Protection. Application development staffs meet all IRM
requirements (including Live Data Request Form approval) before RMODE access will be granted. (
) In order to use the research capability, a user must have command code RMODE in their Production Proﬁle, and input command code S
ON with a Production/Training Indicator of R. (
) An Audit Trail Record will be produced for all inputs made in the research mode.
